sections.title: Appendix I 261 TIPSTER/MUC-5 INFORMATION EXTRACTION TEST SCORES This appendix contains the summary score reports for each Tipster system on the Tipster/MUC-5 evaluation. The reports are ordered by language/domain (EJV, JJV, EME, JME) and secondarily by site (in alphabetical order). Deeper investigation into system performance may be done on the basis of template-by-template score reports, which detail the performance of the system on each article in the test set. The template-by-template score reports are not included in this appendix. A brief introduction to reading the score reports is presented here. Some information on the performance metrics may also be found in the paper, "Tipster/MUC-5 Information Extraction System Evaluation" by B. Sundheim in this volume. Further description of the score report and further definition and explanation of the scoring categories and performance metrics may be found in the MUC-5 proceedings volume in the paper titled "MUC-5 Evaluation Metrics" by N. Chinchor and B. Sundheim. The first column in the report, SLOT, contains one of the following three types of label: A slot name, e.g., content An object name, e.g., <template> The word "subtotals" Of the three types of rows, the one of primary interest is the one labeled with a slot name. The rows labeled with an object name may be disregarded. The rows containing subtotals may be of interest to those interested in performance on the various types of objects in the template. The following tallies for the test set are presented in columns in the score reports: POS ACT COR PAR INC SPU MIS NON Number possible (= COR+PAR+INC+MIS), i.e., the number of fills a system should generate. This value is somewhat variable among systems because of alternative cardinalifies of slot fdls allowed for in the answer key. Number "actual" (= COR+PAR+INC+SPU), i.e., the number of fills generated by the system under evaluation Number correct Number paffially correct Number incorrect Number spurious Number missing Number "noncommittal," i.e., number of null slot fills generated by system, where the fill is also null in the answer key The righUnost columns in the report contain the scores for the following extraction metrics: ERR Error per response fill U N D Undergeneration OV G Overgeneration S U B Substitution REC Recall P R E Predsion = (.5PAR+INC+SPU+MIS)/(COR+PAR+INC+SPU+MIS) = MIS/POS = SPU/ACT = (.5PAR+INC)/(COR+PAR+INC) = (COR+.5PAR)/POS = (COR+.5PAR)/ACT None of the above metrics includes the NON scoring category in its computation. Readers who wish to consider noncommittal fills to be correct may revise the formulas by including NON in all denominators and in those numerators where COR appears. Note, however, that the high undergeneration scores obtained by most systems on many slots in the evaluation places in question the value of considering noncommittal fills to be correct. 262 The fwst two rows at the bottom of the report are the ALL-OBJECTS and MATCHED-ONLY rows. These offer two options in the way the ERR, UND, OVG, SUB, REC, and PRE scores are computed. ALL-OBJECTS gives the official overall tallies and overall ERR, UND, OVG, SUB, REC, and PRE scores. The tallies in POS, ACT, COR, PAR, INC, SPU, MIS, and NON columns add up to the ALL-OBJECTS values, but not all rows are considered. The rows that are not considered are the object rows (i.e., those where the entry in the SLOT column is an object name), the subtotal rows (since they simply sum up the tallies for the scored slots in each object), and the following slot rows in the <template> object: doc-nr, doc-date, and doc-source (these appear only in the EJV and JJV fulltemplate reports). MATCHED-ONLY contains tallies and scores given a method of scoring that eliminates slot-fill penalties in the case where the system under evaluation failed to generate an expected object and in the case where it generated a spurious object. The tallies in the slot rows do

sum up to the totals contained in the MATCHED-ONLY row. The scores for the metrics in the ALL-OBJECTS and MATCHED-ONLY rows are not computed by averaging the scores in the individual slot rows, but instead are computed on the basis of the tally totais contained in the ALL-OBJECTS or MATCHED-ONLY row. The remaining rows at the bottom of the report contain scores for the following metrics: TEXT-FILTERING RICHNESS-NORMALIZED-ERROR ERROR-RATE-PER-WORD F-MEASURES Text filtering (document detection) Richness-normzliTed error (normaliTed version of error per response fill) Error rate per word F-measures (weighted combination of recall and precision) The formulation of each of the above metrics is described below. Text-filtering scores are computed on the basis of relevant/nonrelevant decisions made by the system for the

not on the basis of tallies in the slot rows. Some of the score category columns are used to contain the tallies for these decisions across the test set: COR (decides relevant and relevant is correc0, SPU (decides relevant and nonrelevant is correct), MIS (decides nonrelevant and relevant is coffee0, and NON (decides nonrelevant and nonrelevant is correct). Text-filtering formulas are therefore as follows: REC = COR/(COR+MIS); PRE = COR/(COR+SPU); UND = MIS/(COR+MIS); OVG = SPU/(COR+SPU). Two values of richness-normalized error are computed. The formulas are as follows: Min-err = Wrong/All-fills, Max-err = Wrong/Req-fiils. There will be a range of fill counts from the minimum number of fills required (Req-fllls) to the maximum number of fills allowed (All-fills), according to the answer key. These values are almost, but not quite, system-independent. Error rate per word is computed as Wrong/Word-count. The scores for Japanese are not accurate. F-meastwe scores corresponding to three different weightings of precision relative to recall are computed. The P&R value weights precision the same as recall; the 2P&R value gives twice the weight to precision; the P&2R value weights precision half as much as recall. The general formula is F = (~2+I.0)xPxR/(~i2xp)+R, where 1] is the weighting factor. 263 EJV Summary Scores BBN PLUM System 1. Full-Template Test
